column1: No details about accusations or confession
column5: She had been consulted by someone in Stow.

column9: 48 unnamed individuals were accused by Janet Coutts (C/EGD/1817) after she was searched by George Cathie. The presbytery of Biggar were sceptical about her testimony and brought her to confront those she had named. They found many inconsistencies in her account and after prayer she confessed that she had only accused innocent people because Cathie had promised to prolong her life if she did so. The 48 individuals were therefore not pursued any further.  The case against them was dropped by the presbytery on 29/12/1649.

column2: The demonic pact was suspected but few details

column1: Named as witch in kirk session records but accused of giving advice about healing charms for sick children
column5: Recorded as having told three woman how to heal their sick children

column9: 1 man and 3 woman from Whittingehame were executed.  The execution was attended by the minister.
note that 10 witches burnt in Dunbar and that they were witnessed by a minister.

Several witches mentioned = 3 un-named. They were mentioned several times as trial process took some months but the presbytery records did not list their names.  They refer to a trial held at Jedburgh at which ministers assisted/attended.  Then they were recorded as executed on 16/1/1650 at Oxnam.

column5: Confessed to malefice done to several neighbours but no details

column9: On 12/6/1650 the presbytery minutes recorded that 4 people in Castleton (in the presbytery of Langholm) were suspected of witchcraft and incantation. No names were recorded in the presbytery minutes.  Then on 26/6/1650 ministers were supposed to assist in the execution of the suspects.

column1: Seems to have got into trouble because she advised people to use healing rituals.
column4: Entries record that she advised the use of the blood and feathers of a black hen as a healing charm. Note: black cocks were used to cure the falling sickness but there is no mention of the illness or symptoms she was treating.
column5: No details about the symptoms of illness which she could cure.

column1: Although the Devil was not mentioned specifically it seems that the descriptions of fairies indicated demonic involvement. The king of fairies seemed to = the Devil.
column2: Mentioned that man in black clothes made her go forward and was at meetings with them all. She also referred to one man being the king of fairies who lay with her. She was asked if his nature was hot or cold to which she replied that it was cold. Told minister that she renounced her baptism to the king of fairies.
column3: A number of cats came to her house which turned into men and women. Also went with a group of male and female fairies and one man had sex with her and another woman.
column4: Used water from St Mungo's well to heal her father and spoke verse/charm.
column5: Confessed she and others had caused death of Mr James Ross and one of his children. This may have been the James Ross who was minister at Livingston and who died in 1641.

column1: Demonic as primary as it seems those involved may have read fairies as meaning the Devil or devils. The Devil was only mentioned once compared to several mentions of fairies.
column2: She confessed that she put her own hand on the crown of her head and the other upon the sole of her foot and declared all betwixt the two over to a black man with black clothes and that the devil appeared to her.
column4: Used term 'good neighbours' who wore green kirtalls. The fairies wanted a nurse for one of their own offspring. BP told them to go to a neighbour's house but the woman would not go with them and so her child was killed. This may indicate a changeling type motif but it is not mentioned specifically.
column5: One of the company whirled them all in the wind. Woman in green put sickness on one of her neighbours. She put whirl wind in the house of one of her neighbours and caused the woman to 'rattell till death'.

column9: 'a great many persons' from Musselburgh, Dalkeith, Newbattle, Newton (+ Woomet) and Duddingston but no number or names specified, number calculated as three from each place.  So that is 5 x 3 = 15.  The Privy Council records note that the accused men and women were imprisoned and had already confessed.  A commission of justiciary was issued after petitions from heritors and others from the different parishes.

column1: no details but examined by pricker
Had been examined by pricker for marks.
column2: She was pricked, so they were looking for a Devil's mark.

column1: The information is limited apart from the slandering and counter slandering. The implication is that the minister believed she had caused his ill-health.
column5: Minister Peter Rae requested her to give him back his health. He also appears to have scratched her on the forehead in order to identify her as a witch.
column7: Kirkpatrick and minister involved in complex slander and counter slander case.

column9: Nine unnamed executed for witchcraft and ministers were ordered to assist.

column1: Nothing about accusation or confession.
Noted as having confessed to pact and renunication of baptism but no details from confession or accusation
column2: Commission records that accused confessed to pact and renunciation of baptism, but no details.

column1: Demonic pact and renunciation of baptism noted in RPC but no details of confession or accusations.
column2: RPC entry records that accused confessed to demonic pact and renunciation of baptism but no specific details of confession.

column1: recorded as having confessed pact and renunciation ot baptism but no details from confession

column9: Several people in the parish of Caerlaverock suspected of witchcraft. Only one person named in presbytery records - Bessie Heslope, C/JO/2898.  Presbytery told about number of suspected witches in Caerlaverock. Committee investigated, 27/3/1705, but unsure whether witchcraft proven. Details sent to Queen's Advocate who replied that there were no grounds for criminal process. Presbytery drop the matter on 26/7/1705.

column1: Complicated case as a number of people from the McLean family accused. There may have been some family rivalry between the McLeans and Chisholms and the Chisholms wanted to acquire the lands belonging to the group. Claimed that the McLeans had been 'kindly tenants' for several hundred years.

column3: Confessed that some of the company went to Saltoun with candles.

column9: Referred to as 'the witches of Douglas'. No number given so averaged as 3 suspects.  Note in the Presbytery minutes that brethren were to be sent to Lanark to apprehend the suspects. No details about what happened.

column1: Accused by Janet Coutts, who with George Cathie (pricker) named a large number of people who were later shown to be innocent. In McBirnie's case, however, some neighbours did accuse her of being the cause of some illness and death.
column5: accused of causing William Brown (slaterer) to fall of a house and break his neck after she had exchanged evil words with him. After another falling out with a neighbour she cursed them and prayed that there might be 'blood boils'. Daughter later fell ill

column1: Named by Janet Coutts along with several others
One of the many people denounced by Janet Coutts
One of the many denounced by Janet Coutts
One of several denounced by Janet Coutts
Named as a witch by Janet Coutts

He was suspected then became a star witness.  Not prosecuted.  Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!
column9: Accused but not indicted for witchcraft.  Instead he and his brother were witnesses.  Deemed too young to have made a viable pact with the Devil.  Was not indicted with the large group on 13/4/1697 or tried with the seven who actually stood trial on 12/5/1697.  He was mentioned on the last day of that trial (19/5/1697) in the closing arguments.

column1: The accusations against the two women were not proved by witnesses and the charges dropped. The accuser had to make public repetance.
column2: Accused of having the devil's mark but there was no evidence and the charge was dropped.
column5: Was accused of having caused the death of a woman but the charge was not proven.

column1: The accusations against the two women were not proven by witnesses and the accuser had to make public repentance.

column3: Note that the accused had confessed to attending meetings with the devil.
column9: MacDonald 'The Witches of Fife' (East Linton, 2002) p. 109 indicates that she tried to clear her name in 1654 after being investigated in 1649.

column3: Records note that accused confessed to meetings with the devil but no details.

column9: Un-named witches from Dysart and Fife. Presbytery directed the baillies of Dysart to ensure the suspects were watched and brought to trial.
Unnamed suspects in 2 parishes (Navar and either Strathcathro or Lethnot) in presbytery of Brechin.

column2: Foullthief (or ?foulfiend) - the devil - appeared as a man in her own house. It kissed her but she withdrew from it. Asked how she was able to do so since he was a spirit and she was only flesh and blood. Answered she was very strong.
column5: Accused confessed to causing death of woman and a horse, burning a mill and stealing milk but denied that she had caused the sinking of a ship.

column1: Document implies that suspect may have caused an episode of madness in another woman who received an 'act of witchcraft'.
column5: Accused appears to have cast a 'madness' on another woman who then appears to have pestered a man from the town.

column1: No details about accusations.
First in trouble with the presbytery for charming, although no details given about what kind of charming she carried out.
column4: entry records that she was accused of 'turning the fyne'?

column1: Very little information but the accused was consulted by 1 other to carry out a charm so that they would get the profit back from 'the danke' which was formerly theirs.
column5: Consulted by 2 others to help them get profit back from property that was previously theirs.

column9: Unnamed witches from Tarbat, presbytery of Tain, mentioned in presbytery records - recorded as 3. Minister to write south for advice about the case but no further details in records.
I think these suspects from Thurso are the same as C/EGD/2461, C/EGD/2462, C/EGD/2085, C/EGD/2086, C/EGD/2087 and C/EGD/2088, who all have their own records. I have recorded this total as zero.

column1: Accused appears to have been refused alms but also consulted for healing advice. The whole family appear to have been unpopular and asking for charity.
column4: Accused appears to have advised a man to go to Sandness church, and sit in the dark and smoke some tobacco and he would be cured of a sickness, which he claimed had been caused by being given a banock by one of the Ratter sisters.
column5: She had asked for some corn, which was refused, Told the person that she had got corn from her neighbour the previous year and the neighbour had a very good crop. Implied threat to the crop.
column7: Presbytery notes that the accused was declared as a 'deluder and abuser of the people'.

column1: The family seems to have been unpopular and asking for alms, which were refused.
column4: Witnesses claimed she cursed a man saying 'God should swarfin his body and his ground' and later the man's body decayed. Swarf - to faint or swoon. Also told family of sick woman who was having blood let that this would not help her. Woman later died.
column5: Accused appears to have argued/cursed her neighbours after disputes. Later sickness/death blamed on her. Refused alms, child of house took ill and died - witnesses claimed he had a 'blue weed' (?fever).
column7: Charged with being a 'deluder and abuser of the people'.

column1: She was investigated at the same time as the Ratter family, and appears to have been unpopular because she asked for charity.
column4: Cursed people but no record of what she said.
column5: Asked if she was a witch, but denied accusation. Was refused lodgings, later the woman of the house took bad dreams and was out of her wits. Watson agreed that she cursed people if they wronged her.
column7: Accused was charged as being a 'deluder and abuser of the people', in 1708. In 1725 the steward found nothing that would infer the crime of witchcraft but that she was a deluder of the people and he intended to proceed against her.
column8: Denied she could be a witch and not know it in 1708.

column1: The Ratter family appear to have been very unpopular, asking for alms and arguing. In Andrew's case the list of harm done was more extensive than his sisters.
column5: Accused shared drink with another man at the peat cutting, man later took ill. Animals took ill or born dead after arguments. Refused butter - cow died later. Given alms (some bread) which he threw in fire, the family then had no calves born alive.
column7: Accused of being a' deluder and abused of the people'.

column9: Note that Mr James Blair (minister at Portpatrick) and other ministers were to attend to commission for trial of witches the next day. Later reported that this had been delivered.

column1: It seems that Kennedy was consulted to witch another woman to death, but not clear how she did this or if it worked. The consulter claimed that she only did this in order to prove that Kennedy was a witch.
column5: It seems that Kennedy was consulted by another woman to witch 'Mistress Mowat to death' although it is not clear if this worked. Kennedy was promised beef and tobacco if she did it. The consulter got in trouble as well.

column4: Accused of causing illness of a neighbour. Seen carrying a stoup of water while her hair was loose about her ears. The man also claimed to be troubled by a great number of cats - but does not suggest that Sinclair appeared in the shape of a cat.

column1: Wharrie took the case herself to presbytery. She tied to prove that the witnesses had malice against her. Witnesses claimed that she had cursed them after they had refused to help her with ploughing or prevented her from crossing their land. It seems that the presbytery were not convinced by Wharrie's version but could not really do much with her.
column4: It was cliamed that she cursed and swore at her victims.
column5: Witnesses claimed she cursed and uttered an 'ill prayer' that a neighbour's wife 'would have many a bloody day'. Also cows would vomit their grass or rowt/rout (bellow) to death. Also wished a man to take the glengore (syphilis).
column6: Wharrie asked neighbours to help with ploughing. When they refused they claimed she cursed their beasts and ploughs so that they could not use them to plough their own rigs.

column9: 4 women in Caerlaverock suspected of witchcraft.  Presbytery investigated the suspects and noted that the moderator was to write to the sheriff depute to get commission to secure them 'their due trial'. Mr Paton reported that the sheriff was going to write for the commission but they presbytery felt that they should also write to the Privy Council. No further details.

Un-named witches mentioned by Dumfries presbytery as being in prison. Also named with Janet Wharrie (C/JO/3025).  Presbytery recorded that the group of witches were in prison and Mr Veitch was appointed to send the processes to the King's Advocat. There seems to have been a long delay before Mr Blair reported that the King's advocat said there was nothing so 'momentous as to require a commission to put them to trial'. Ministers appointed to inquire about their imprisonment but no mention if they were released or if the investigation was dropped.

column1: Claimed in Helene Frasser's dittay that Hendersoune was instructed in the pact by Frasser.
column2: Hendersoune was told to put her hand on her head and foot by Helen Frasser and to 'beteich quhatevir was betwein hir handis to the Devil' and she would want for nothing, but Hendersoune did not confess to this.

column1: Andro Man claimed that Moress had learned his witchcraft from his wife.
Bane's association with Spaldarge seems to have condemned her although Bane herself seems to have named quite a few others.
column2: Confessed that her sister Spaldarge had taught her all her skill and witchcraft, and inducted her to the devil's service.
column3: In Issobell Richie's dittay it was claimed that Issobell had taken Bane to meetings with the devil and other witches, but no detail from Bane herself.
column4: With her sister Spaldarge, she seems to have had a vision of a headless man, which they claimed predicted the death of a man. Seen paddling in loch on Nuris Day, throwing water and erd and stane (ritual of land ownership) over her shoulders. Took fire peat from one man's house to her own house and later daughter/son (?) of the man died. Predicted the birth of a child. Did not exchange any greeting with a man who later died. Touched boy on both cheeks, later he died.
column5: Claimed with Issobell Richie she performed acts of malefice. Consulted as midwife to help labour pains, which were transferred to other people. Helped with calf not suckling, but later wife took ill.Cursed man after he said she would burn. He drowned.
column6: Accused  of cursing a man who had argued and hit her son, Duncan Gardyne.

column4: gave Issobell Richie a magic belt which if it was ?lost (tyne) would cause the death of bearded men. It was claimed that the belt was a sign of the devil.

column1: Implicated by assocation with her mother (M. Bane) who was burnt for witchcraft.
column4: Accused of having caused her daughter-in-law's illness, which was made worse with some milk that was given to her by Rogie's own mother (M. Bane). Was seen to be carrying out some strange ritual of measuring some land and building a cairn of stones and also casting 'yerd and stane' over her shoulder. Erd and stane was a symbolic ritual associated with land ownership. Rogie did not answer the person who saw her carry out the ritual, who then took ill and died. An image of a man, made of soft lead (?wax/clay) was found in her purse.
column5: Accused of having cast an illness onto her daughter-in-law (aided by her mother Margaret Bane). Caused oxen and horse of a male neighbour to run wild and die.

column3: meeting the same as several others which were ascribed to Margaret Bane. There does not appear to be any evidence from Robbie about the meetings. Bane claimed Robbie went with her mother and they all dacned round the grey stone.
column4: Accused of having caused the death of a woman by giving her some mutton that Robbie and her mother (Margaret Og) had bewitched. Also accused of having carried out a special ritual (?protective) with her mother. They threw a knife 3 times over a cow while it was at the bull ?to ensure a fertile union.
column5: Accused of having aider her mother bewitch and cause the death of Lady Auchinhuiff by giving her some mutton that was bewitched,

column4: Accused of having spoken a curse, which then caused a man's horse to fall, break its bones and later die. Also claimed to know how to keep a man's health. Take a cog of water, put three straws in it and put it on the back of a sick cow. Then take some water and put it in the cow's mouth, then put an arm down the cow's throat, which will cure a cow. Also accused of throwing water three times for an evil purpose. Was able to locate lost/stolen money. Claimed that she predicted an outbreak of smallpox.
column5: To preserve health carry the bones of a linnet in clothing as a form of talisman.

column1: The accusations about Paplay come from the questioning of another suspect (Barbara Boundie). No details seem to have come from Paplay herself and her son denied all the charges. Bowndie then claimed that she had been encouraged to name other 'honest' women in return for her own life.

column2: Said the devil appeared in several diverse shapes
column3: She later denied that she had attended the meeting and dancing at Muness. Her stories seem to have got confused as she later retracted most of it and claimed she had been urged to name others
column4: Her statement said that she had been speechless for 1 day and people had said she had been taken by the fairies, she denied this. She denied that she was able to identify other witches.
Accused of being able to locate stolen goods but no details.

column5: Most of the accusations relate to disputes over cows. Neighbours accused her of causing illness and death of cows after arguments. Also one case of healing human.

column2: She confes ed to meeting the fair folk, then the devil appeared as an angel but also in the form of a human male, who she named. She confessed that the 'fair folk' and the angel offered to protect her if she served them.
column3: The meetings were with the 'fair folk' and attended by herself and several others including Richie Graham. There is a lot about food.
column4: Claimed to have used rowan tree and a piece of a dead person's finger to cure the worm. Fairies offered her food but she refused it. Her husband took ill, then her baby was replaced with a changeling. She refused to feed it and threw it in the fire. She then promised to serve the 'fair folk' in return for her child. Said the saw Richie Graham at meetings with the 'fair folk' as well as several other people. While in prison she was visited by a man and asked to identify who had stolen his cow's milk. The man and the woman that Watsonne identified were questioned by the presbytery.
column5: Accused and confessed to healing a man of the worm using rowan tree.

column1: Devil's mark found by witch pricker so demonic included.
column2: Searched for mark but no details.
column9: Identified by a witch pricker. Larger group named each other. Witch pricker then employed and identified marks on 3 others.

column1: The accusations all came from one other woman, although both accused and accuser produced lots of witnesses, and relate to something to do with giving the other woman malt to make her husband's malt improve but not sure if it worked. McNab herself later confessed to knowing how to make a cow accept a calf that did not belong to her. Characterised as neighbourhood dispute since this was the accuser's main reason.
column5: Confessed that she knew how to make a cow accept another calf. Put the skin of the dead calf onto the other calf before the cow licked it. This is a common enough agricultural practice. Presbytery seem to have thought it might be witchcraft.

column2: Another woman claimed that there were black dogs at meetings of witches, but Murray said nothing about this.
column3: Another woman accused Murray of attending dancing with a group of witches. Murray did not appear to make any statement about this.
column5: Cursed man who later took sick. Also with a woman who died. Told a woman in labour that there were cats in her womb, the woman later died. She agreed that she cursed/argued but denied she caused harm.
column6: She denied that she had taken away the substance of milk.

column5: Minister of Dalmeny claimed that Lauson had cursed him while on her bare knees.

column1: Accused of observing the Lord's Supper in a Catholic way, although she denied this. No other details of any witchcraft.
column4: Seems to have been accused of observing the Lord's supper in a papistical way. She denied all charges.

column1: No information about Murray herself but mentioned in a slander case. Woman was slandered that she had consulted Murray who was a suspect of witchcraft. The presbytery noted that Murray had not been convicted of witchcraft at her trial and the case against the other woman was dismissed.

column3: Claimed she met the devil at neighbour's house, in the little chalrmer (room), where they shared some wine. Other women present.
column9: A group of people (including Garner) appear to have been investigated and recorded in the kirk session records. A further 2 were identifed by a pricker but no details about them
There seems to have been a group (including Boswell) investigated. Another 2 were identified by pricker but no details.

column2: Confessed that she had carnal relations with the devil and he was as 'cold as ice'.
column5: Accused of causing the death of a child.
column7: Accused of causing the death of a child but not of child murder.
column9: Part of a group (including Potter) who were investigated. Another 2 were identified by pricker but no details

column2: Confessed that she made a covenant with the devil
column9: Named in a group (including Lodge) who were investigated and tried at Dysart. The accusations stemmed from one and spread out. Another 2 were identified by a pricker but few details.
A number of people were investigated by the kirk session, some were found guilty, others searched for the mark but the fate of most is unknown.

column2: Was searched and mark seems to have been found, but no details.
column4: She was requested to take the sickness off a child, who it was thought she had made ill.
column5: Accused of having made a child ill after a dispute and requested to restore the child's health by its mother.
column9: A group including (Burt) were investigated by kirk session. Another 2 were identified by pricker but few details.

column1: Demonic included as KS noted he had been searched.
column2: KS records that a mark was found on him but no details.
column3: Male witness told kirk session that Quhyt had been drinking in Kirkcaldy although there does not seem to have been any demonic involvement in this drinking sesssion.
column9: Part of a group who were investigated by kirk session. Another 3 were identified by pricker.

column1: No details but witch pricker claimed to find devil's mark.
column2: KS notes that she was searched and a mark found but no details.
column9: Indentified by witch pricker. There was bigger group who named each other. Witch pricker was then employed and identified some of the group and 3 others.

column1: Investigated for use of charms
column5: Investigated for use of charms but no details.

column1: Charges appear to relate to charming rituals, which may have gone wrong. There is no mention of any demonic elements.
column4: Used a belt as part of a healing ritual (met the belt).

column1: Important note about process, they were involved in watching and warding (i.e. sleep deprivation) to try and get confessions.  Also a pricker was brought in to test for the Devil's mark.
column9: Investigations by Stow kirk session. No names listed. Group were imprisoned and there was ongoing discussions about watching and warding. Kirk session wrote to presbytery trying to get financial support for the trial process.  On 8/1649 the situation was referred to the local magistrate.

column1: This is all about healing but the presbytery referred to it as witchcraft.
column4: Claimed to heal the gut using water and butter.
column5: Claimed he healed the gut and learned it from another called (illegible) Campbell. His mother could cure broken bones?

column1: Appear to have been about using charms, which later became accusation of witchcraft, but no details.
There seems to have been quite a lot of healing or failed healing but a lot of the accusations seem to have involved neighbourhood disputes. Most of the witnesses were men.
column5: Descriptions of healing rituals but most of the accusations involved either failed healing, transfer of sickness or causing illness after dispute.

column1: Named by Jonet Tailzour but many witnesses gave evidence about her malefice, which often resulted from disputes and insults.
column5: She seems to have cursed and quarrelled quite a bit and accusations revolved around perceived harm after arguments.
column6: Accused of harming goods and gear after insults and disputes.

column1: She was noted as being consulted for childbirth, so was most likely involved in midwifery.  But we donât have any specific information about Drummond other than what Paton said in her trial.

column2: She was named as the woman with the black pock at several Devil's meetings.
column3: accused of being at several Witches' meetings with a black pock, and using meal from the pock to kill children.

column1: Accused of malefice after revenge but cleared of charges. Also seems to have consulted Margaret Bane.
column4: Predicted or threatened that a man's children would not live, because he would not die. Her prediction came true,
column5: Threatened a man that his children would not live, because he would not marry her. Also accused of taking revenge on her previous employer who had taken some of her belongings after she left his house.

column1: Seems to also have been in trouble for sexual misconduct and had been excommunicated in the past.
column2: Confessed that the devil appeared in her bed between herself and her ?harlot, William Richie. Also said that if she was to die as a witch then he should do so as well because if she was a witch then he was one too.
column4: Seen hugging the corners of a man's house at dawn. He later took ill and died. Prophesied that a man who had taken on a property would lose it all. Seen to have thrown stones in water, which then appeared to dance. No details about what they were for. Seen to turn the bowl of her shears 3 times in the mouth of her sheep.
column5: Accused of causing a man's illness and death. She was seen hugging the corners of his house at dawn. Seen to have metted a sheep, the threw water between her feet and into the sheep's face. The sheep died.

column4: Accused of taking three hairs from her cow's tail, cutting it into pieces and putting them in the trough. Later her cow gave milk but her neighbour's did not. Accused of taking a calf under her arm to charm it.  She told a woman to bury clippings from the front hooves in her yard. Carried a newborn calf three times round its mother.
column5: Took a calf under her arm, then (?) told woman to bury clippings from the front hooves in her yard.

column4: Gave a woman a 'tabblet' and a ring to use as a love magic talisman.
column5: Her son claimed that his mother had promised that her magic would protect him (it did not as he was hanged). Also cured a man but transferred the sickness to his sister. Stole livestock.
column6: Stole a man's livestock and killed some his other beasts.

column9: There seems to have been others accused at the same time, but not named (C/JO/3106).
Un-named others accused at the same time as Margaret Coul (C/JO/3105).

column1: Although accused of variety of rituals, which caused harm to others but from which he benefited, but charges were not sufficient to advance to trial.
column4: Accused of using rituals involving taking nine handfuls of earth from one man's rig and throwing on to his own. Accused of going withershins about a kiln in which he was drying corn. Said to have thrown water on the threshhold of a neighbour's house causing his servant to flee.
column6: Accused of taking the milk from another woman's cow. Accused of measuring (metting) another man's crops with a white wand and stiking them 9 times so that nothing would grow.

column4: Accused of healing a woman of the fevers with a sleeve and thread. Said to have brought a burning coal out her house at Hallowe'en and buried it in her yard.
column5: Accused of causing the death of a man after an argument.

column1: Charges dropped as no evidence, although she was was cautioned to keep out of trouble.
Mother was accused of malefice but there are no specific accusations against the daughter.

Petition to parliament from Earl of Haddington. He claimed that witchcraft was increasing in his lands and had imprisoned some of the suspects. He also claimed that two of them were accused of robbery as well.
appears to have been imprisoned for witchcraft and released. Kirk session the note that she had practised charming.
Demonic included as she was searched by the pricker. Appears to have confessed to charming.
demonic included as she was searched by a pricker
demonic included as she was searched by the pricker
demonic included as she was searched by a pricker, also she confessed to charming
denomic included as she was searched by a pricker

column2: Pact implied as she was searched but does not appear to have confessed to any aspects of pact.
column5: Accused of having caused the death of a neighbour's horse.

column1: Church records disciplining a woman for consulting her for advice about her sick husband.

column5: Accused of causing a cow to stop giving milk

column1: Associated with Katherine Ross (Lady Fowlis) so political and property added as secondary characteristics.
Associated with Katherine Ross (Lady Fowlis) so political and property added as secondary characteristics.
The description looks like it could have developed into a demonic possession style case.
column2: Accused by a young man (18 years old) of having cast an illness on him after he said her goodame was a witch. Claimed he took fits when he was unable to speak, and that she appeared to him in his bed. Also said he saw her with other woman and a man, that they put a bridle on him and rode him like a horse. The church seemed a bit dubious about this, she denied it all and was absolved.
column5: Accused of having caused a young man to take fits which caused him to speak in tongues, then be unable to speak or stand unaided. The church repeatedly asked him if he dreamt this.
column9: The process notes record that she was investigated on 26/2/1699 and 25/4/1699.  But she was absolved on 14/3/1699.  These dates don't match up, but this is how they were entered in the Presbytery minute books.  It could be that the final date was the date that the earlier proceedings were recorded.  We don't know.

column2: It was claimed that she had confessed to pact and renunciation of baptism.

3 marks found. Said she refused to go with the devil but he grabbed her left leg. Third time she agreed and he put his mouth on her sore and healed it. She gave him a hen or a cock as a gift. Said at the time that she was in great poverty the devil promised to help but in return she was to give him her son. He gave her an elfshot to use on her son who died 10 days later.
column4: One report said she was seen to go round cows several times. Lifted up her curcheffe and cursed to cause harm. Said she knew a charm in Gaelic to cure the evil eye.
column5: Claim that she caused a horse and man to fall ill after an argument. Also a child of the man died suddenly. She cursed a man who threatened to poind her daughter for a debt.

column1: This was mostly about theft but he the confessed to attending meetings, which sound like outdoor conventicles, but which were identified as devilish. Claimed one of the meetings was at a fairy mound.
column2: He was told not to tell anyone about the meetings but he did not keep his word and told another man. In punishment he was struck on his cheek.
column3: Saw a gathering of men and women led by an old man. There were lots of candles and he saw them dancing. He said that a woman took his details. He judged the men to have been 'worldie' men or men 'ordayned of god'. They asked if he was baptised (he was) but did not give him a new name. I think this sounds like some form of outdoor religious meeting.
column4: Confessed that the devil told him about stolen goods. Said that he met the others on top of the hill on a Sabbath.

column1: Although she reported a lot about malefice she did not claim that she was involved. Only confessed to demonic features and healing. Margret McLevine claimed that Morisone had been involved in the intended harm of the minister John Stewart and the provost John Glass - ?was their some local political thing going on.
column2: She met a black rough man at night who promised to make her a 'Lady' with a grand castle. She refused at first then agreed to meet him after he grabbed her hand. She knew he was the devil. He told her he would free her from poverty and he would teach her how to bring home Adam Ker. Said she was to be taken to Knockane. At night she heard a voice which told her to go and buy ale (her husband slept through it). She claimed the voice said he was Adam Ker and he wanted in - she refused. A voice spoke to her one time and told her to drown herself.
column3: On one occasion she met a great number of people and one of them came to her in white or as a naked man with a black head. Claimed she saw the devil in the company of other people, whom she named. They gathered in a ring, the devil came and conveyed her to the Loaning.
column4: Used herbs to heal. Said the devil told her the fairies took John Glas's child's life, and that they intended to take Glas's life as well. Said that an illness was caused by the fairies - 'blasted by the fairies'. Asked what the difference was between shooting (elfshot) and blasting. Said there was no cure for shot and that blasting was a whirlwind that the fairies raised about their victim but that it could be healed with herbs or charms.
column5: Used herbs to heal. Said the devil told her to kill animals and humans in order to restore health to another person or bring someone back from the dead. She said she refused. Asked to heal a cow - took off her curch and hit the cow 3 times with it.
column6: Claimed that other witches caused a lot of damage to property - lot of detail about what they did but she does not say that she was involved.

column2: Devil as a man, according to Hammilton.  He claimed that the Devil had sex with Gilmore in a den.
column3: Accused of having a Devil's meeting near the how of the deane (valley) on the way to Edmestoun.  She supposedly had sex with the Devil along with K. Oswald for 15 min on the side of the den (according to Hammilton).

column1: They were clearly the victims of a quest for suspects from Alexander Hammilton.  There is some evidence of neighbourhood disputes -  especially around a horse that went mad and a possibly suspicious healing done on John Hog where the disease may have gone over to a neighbour's baby.  But this healing was done on John Hog not by him or his wife.  Their family was also questioned.  Hog was accused of trying to seduce his neighbour's wife.
column2: Lots of accusations regarding the Devil in depositions given in by Hamilton, but did not include them here because he retracted them and Hog and wife never confessed.  Both Hog and his wife made an oath on their knees denying everything in Hammilton's depositions.
column4: There is a description of a possible unwitching episode that was attempted on John Hog where a disease was transferred to a newly born baby.  Lots of information about this event in JC26/9 item 7.  There is something about a strange cat found in Margaret's house and a din of cats that was seen and heard at her neighbours around Michaelmas.  She was also accused of divination.
column9: She was denounced by Hammilton, investigated the authorities and the case was dropped.  Lots of detail in JC26/9, She quarreled with lots of people and he was accused of trying to seduce his neighbour's wife.  Witness statements from 7 November 1629 through until 23 November 1629 - intensive questioning of neighbours and family members by Colville and the Bishop of Dunblane.  Hamilton was known to beg at their house.

column1: Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!
column3: see Agnes Naismith for details (c/egd/1773)
column4: allegedly part of a group that used image magic to kill people
column9: Part of the Renfrewshire cases of 1697 - released on caution

column1: I think she was a neighbourhood dispute person who got caught up in the 1699 Refrewshire possession cases.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
column9: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

column1: She was accused of tormenting Margaret Murdoch and Margaret Laird.  Both girls displayed all the typical symptoms that have been described as 'demonic possession' - but the record refers to it as 'tormenting'.  Both girls spit and vomitted foreign object (hair, pins, stones, wool), had convulsions, bite and nip markes on their bodies and faces, extraordinary strength, the ability to sense when their tormenters were near, bruises and blisters, excessive thrashing, and clothes falling off.  Both girls were attended by physicians and ministers in order to diagnose and help them.
column5: All the accusations were for tormented girls.
column9: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, and Margaret Murdoch in Govan.  Both girls claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird  and Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699, from Laird) and  Glasgow (22 April 1699 from Murdoch).  Testimony came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

column1: Accused by Margaret Laird of being her tormentor.  See Agnes Supp for a description of the tormenting/possession.  Wasnât' accused of anything else.  The testimony is from people who witnessed Laird denounce many people while in the midst of fits.
column9: Was not tried, just denounced as being one of the tormentors of Margaret Laird - no evidence that legal action was taken.   6 men and 1 woman testified against her at Paisley between 19-21 April.

She was examined by a doctor and many ministers.  Although suspected, Robertson doesn't appear to have been proceeded against.  1 man testified against him in Glasgow 22 April 1699.

column1: The whole case revolved around her confession to meetings and sex with the Devil.  Folk healing was an incidental mention in the trial text.
column2: Claimed to learn her healing from the Devil.  She was asked what her new name was and said she didn't have one, but that the Devil gave her a nip on her back.
column3: a small drinking party with 2 pints of 'beir'
column4: The Devil told her to heal a man by laying a black caird under his door.  The Devil supplied the black caird.  She said that she didn't keep the kirk regularly and that was why the Devil came to her.
column9: She was questioned at least three times.  She was tried with Margaret Lauder.  It seems that Barker was arrested first and implicated Lauder (who had brought Barker cake while in prison).  Lauder said that Barker had been imprisoned four years earlier for fornication.

column1: Barker and Lauder testified against her.  Barker seems to have started the accusation train?
column3: A drinking party with M. lauder and J. Barker.

column9: Had 23/7/1605 entered but no source mentioned and no details?  So I have changed the date the match Ayr Burgh Accounts date for her execution.

Some women in from Brechin were executed.  A particularly graphic description of local justice - the women were tried and convicted (although they denied the charges) and 'wes brunt quick efter sic ane crewell maner that sum of thame deit in dispair, renunceand and blasphemeand, and utheris, half brunt, brak out of the fyre and wes cast in quick in it againe quhill thay war brunt to the deid.'

A commission for trial of witches by Earl Merschell.  The Bishops think that more commissions of this kind should be granted.  They argued that it was too expensive and inconvenient for people to come to Edinburgh for trials.  But they advise the council to take care in deciding about commissions.

The first of two commissions granted for Galloway.  The second was granted in 1615.  The two commissions were for arrest and justiciary.  2nd commission stressed that the bishop was to advice the others in the process.
This is the second of two commission issued for Galloway.  The first was issued in 1614.

column1: She was denounced by Hammilton, but she was already dead.  She was described as having been 'delate to be ane witche'.

column9: Witchcraft was exepted from the benefit of passification.  I think this means that other crimes will be pardoned but not witchcraft. [passed by the Regent Morton]
witchcraft cannot be remitted by the purchasing of a remittance.

Call for criminal cases to be heard by James VI starting 27/11/1587 in Edinburgh then travelling throughout the realm.  Witchcraft is listed (towards the end) as one of the crimes to be tried.  No suspects are listed.

column1: denounced by Alexander Hammilton (c/egd/166)
column2: called to the meeting by a spirit.
column6: burned down a mill; destroyed ships during the herring drove.

did not appear for charges of witchcraft and declaired a rebel.
He and Ninane Chirnside were declared rebels for failing to appear on charges of witchcraft and treason
column9: No trial process, the servitor and his servant (unknown Nesbitt)failed to appear personally before king James VI at Holyrood palace on 6 March 1591 to answer charges of witchcraft and treason.

This was a commission for the people listed in the 'people' section to arrest, interrogate, torture and try suspected witches.  It basically says that the use of torture is OK to get people to confess.  It is an open commission, meaning there are no specified suspects.  I have left the number of suspects at zero because this commission is so general and because we already have many people tried during this time in the database.

The king ordered that blank (of noblemen, barons, gentlemen and magistrates) commissions should be passed under the signet and by the subscription for the clerk of Privy Council to the General Assembly for them to hand out as they saw fit for maters of witchcraft.    They could issue these blank commissions for arrest, investigation, and trial of witches.  The commissions to expire on 1/11/1592.  This was granted in response to the fallout around allegations of witchcraft and consulting directed at the Earl of Bothwell and associates.

His majesty ordered that requests for commissions of justiciary for the crimes of theft, receiving of stolen property, slaughter, murder, witchcraft and other capital crimes were not to be submitted to him personally.  They were to go to the Kings secretary and then delivered to the Privy Council for deliberations.  'Commissions otherwise passed are to be  .'

Sir William Steward of Houston, commendator of Pittenweem was appointed with the power to grant all commissions for the Highlands and Islands for a specified length of time in order to promote law and order.  He was authorised to hold courts for the crimes of fire-raising, ravishing of women, murder, slaughter, counterfitting, false coinage, theft, receiving of stolen property, witchcraft, sorcery, enchantment, sorning, oppression etc.

A revocation of previously granted commissions for the arrest, investigation and trial of suspects of witchcraft, sorcery, enchantment and devilish practices.  People of high rank could apply for a new commission if they had known witches in their lands.  [seems to be a sort of clearing house for open ended commissions?]
Commission of Lieutenancy in the West March to Andrew, Lord Ochiltree to ward and hold justice courts on people he saw fit, including witchcraft suspects.

column1: Consulted a witch for seduction.
column4: He tried to use witchcraft and potions to seduce the daughter of his employer, 'by the dobbing on ane apple and ifusing of ane portioun of his awn natur in it' and getting her to eat it, laced her drink with 'Spaniyie fleis, gave her a drink made with daphindillie, then consulted a witch.  None of this worked so he raped her.
column9: More a case about rape and consulting, but provides interesting information about the services and potions provided by 'witches'.

Commission of justiciary and lieutenancy within the bounds of the the South and West Isles to Ludovick, Duke of Lennox.  It includes witchcraft with the usual list of 10-20 different crimes.  A search through his papers may yeild witchcraft prosecutions?
commission granted to apprehend and try 'sundry persons' within the bounds of Galloway.
commission granted to the Steward of Kirkudbright to apprehend and try divers persons for witchcraft in Galloway, he was to consult with the Bishop of Galloway before proceeding with executions.
just have an order for release from prison after being clenged for witchcraft.  Could be a duplicate with earlier Jonet Thompson(s).  No way to tell.

column9: Duns and Chirnside in the Merse.  They requested a commission for the trial of 'diverse both men and weomen' who are suspected of witchcraft.  They had already petitioned for a commission once and were denied.  6 unnamed witches can be estimated - three from each presbetery.

A privicy council decision in the wake of the Geilis Johnston case that the kirk and presbyteries can handle matters of witchcraft when they are simply a mater of idolitry and heresy if the person confesses.  If the suspect denies the charges the case must be handed over to the  'juge ordinar'.  The church can still investigate.  I don't know how this ruling played out in practice?

Ruling that it was not lawful to arrest a person merely on suspicion of witchcraft unless they were caught red-handed doing something like raising dead bodies and taking joints or dancing in the Kirk at midnight.  Suspected witches had to be first summoned and questioned, like any other criminal suspect, before being arrested.  If they are summond and do not appear, they are fugitive and can be arrested when found.
The privy council specified that witchcraft, sorcery and necromancy  are under the jurisdiction of the circuit courts.
An open commission for the bailies to search for, arrest and examine suspected witches in his lands.  Required to report back to the Privy Council before trying anybody.
'In expenses sustenit in the burning of the witche of Barnweill, in candillis, hir meit and drink, pyk barrellis, colis, rosat, heddir, treis and uther necessaris, Â£7, 3s. 8d.'

Payment for the messanger, 'twice summoning the assize in Kyle, Carrick and Cunningham' (Â£7).  And for burning - 'for coles, cordis, tar barrellis and uther graith that burnit Mareoun Greiff witche, Â£4, 4s.'
List of crimes that the Privy Council wants the circuit courts to try.  'Charmers and consulters with witches and sorcerers' is the 3th item listed, after making false coin and communing with rebels.

The Moderator and elders request that the Privy Council order local nobles to make space in their jails for witchcraft suspects.  They thank the Earl of Morton for the use of his prison, but he now needs it for delinquents.  The PC ordered that space be made and that the presbytery report back to PC for commissions as per usual.

The Privy Council 'prorogatis' the commissions granted to the presbytery of Haddinton for the trial of witches until the next council day, and orders the depositions to be sent to the Bishop of St. Andrews to report back to the PC on their next meeting.
She died in prison during the winter of 1671-2.

column1: She consulted with Reid to destroy David Libbertoun a burgess baxter in Edinburgh.  I think Reid was hired to remove a bewitchment, he seemed to be taking off lots of illnesses in the Chrystie household, and guiding the attack on D. Libberton for the Chrysties not himself.
column4: Reid prepared an enchanted piece of flesh for her to lay under her enemies stable door.
column5: She supposedly wanted to get someone, and used Reid to do it.  Reid was a healer, so this may have been somekind of unwitching thing, because lots of members of her family underwent healing rituals from Reid.

column2: According to Patrick Lowrie she was presented with a hairbelt in the shape of a devil's claw by Helena McBurnie, the 'devilish spirit woman' according to P. Lowrie.

column4: She was presented with a hairbelt (in the shape of a Devil's claw) from the spirit woman Helena McBurnie according to P. Lowrie, and involved in meetings at Halloween and Whitsunday.

column4: According to Tod she did rituals with a cat and named it Margaret.

column1: He was described as a doctor of medicine.  Although there is a lot of information about him, it is all from the trial of Alesoun Pierson, not from his own trial.  Therefore the characterisation has to be implicated by another witch, but some detail is provided in the notes fields.
column4: According to Alison Pierson his father was the king's smith.  He was taken away from his father by one man of Egypt, one gyant, while he was a bairn.  He lived their for 12 years.  His father supposedly died because he opened a 'preist-buik' and looked at it.  Perhaps Pierson was learning from him while she lived with him at the age of 12.  The fairies told Pierson that Sympsoune was one of them.  Pitcairn quotes the 'Legend of the Bischop of St. Androis' for his case.  He told Pierson that he had been carried away (out of middle earth) with the Fairies and that when a whirlwind was heard that was them.  Mention of a tithe to hell.
column5: He supposedly cured Pierson when she lost the power of her hand and foot.

column1: He was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheretance of land, titles, and property
column4: Katherine Ross, sent Christiane Roiss to him to purchase some elfshot. No details from McNilland.

column6: Claimed by others that he was part of the witches' crew that wanted to destroy king James VI and Queen Ann by sinking their ships.

column1: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.

She was supposedly part of the conspiracy treason plot, planned the first assault against the Queen's ship.  She was in charge of a letter and some cat rituals to raise wind. Attended a meeting at the saltpans.
column4: Said to have used a cat in rituals.
column6: Said to have been involved in trying to raise winds and storms to sink the royal ships.

column9: The bailies reprimand a crowd of friends and family who protested to delated witches.  Specifically the 'vindictive, injurious, and opprobrius speaches' uttered at the bailies.  Fines were then imposed for the breach at the ward.

In a letter from Roger Aston to Robert Bowes, he laments the death of the chancelor and reports other news including about the three witches.  'The Earl of Caithness has sent hither three witches out of Caithness that dealt with the Earl Bothwell at his being there'.

In a letter from George Nicolson to Robert Bowes.  He narrates many matters including: 'Many witches are taken and burnt in the Merse, some for mean, some for greater matters.'  I estimated three for 'many witches' in accordance with our standard practice.

In a letter from Robert Bowes to Burghley.  He describes that a Duch gentlewoman from Lubeck sought the King of Scots at Elsinore, but not finding him there came to Edinburgh with a prophesy from good witches.  James VI agreed to hear her.
I am counting this as zero witches because it is in reference to the 'North Berwick'.  It says he was occupied with the 'examination' of sundry witches.

Letter from Roger Aston to James Hudson, set at zero witches because it is commentary regarding the investigations into the North Berwick witches.  'We are busy examining witches, who confess many strange things'

A letter from Robert Bowes to Burghley.  'Some of the worst sort of witches - discovered here -  are eschaped and fled into England.'  James VI sent David Seaton of Tranent, gentleman, to find them and bring them back for trial.

column5: accused of killing his father
column9: a note in a letter from Robert Bowes to Burghley (13/2/1591).  A second mention of him in another letter from Bowes to Burghley (23/2/1591).  Yet a third mention in letter of the same people (24/3/1591).  He has still not been handed over.  I have not selected a trial type since he was out of the country.

A woman was brought back to Scotland from ward in England.  The King was reportedly very pleased.  The woman 'hath accused many others, and if found to have practiced sundry wicked actions by her sorceryes.'  I count the woman as one and the 'many others' as three unnamed witches in accordance with our standard estimating practice.

Letter from Robert Bowes to Burghley in which he says he is sceptical about the truth in the confessions and testimony from the King's examination of witches.  He said they confessed to abusing God's name and yeilding themselves to evil spirits.  He thinks the confessors were 'suborned'.  He objects to himself being described by a witch as 'a little black and fatt man with black haire'.  He said she got his description wrong so the other information she provided may also be wrong.  Also points to John Fean's recanting his testimony at his execution.

A letter from Bowles to Burghley about the 1590-1 witches.  He provides part of Agnes Sampsoune's confession, lists a number of people who were burnt in Haddington, says 'ane in Dalkeith', 'ane in Dumfreish' were also executed so I will count 2 unnamed witches.  Because we know who the Haddington ones were.

column1: Instructions from James VI as to how to handle some of the North Berwick, treason-cum-witchcraft trials.
column9: A letter from James VI to Maitland, to examine Barbara Napier to see if she was really pregnant - 'if she be not, to the fyre uith her presentlies, and cause bouell her publicclie.'  'let Effie Makkaillen see the stoup twa or three dayes, and upon the suddain staye her in hope of confession.'  The rest of the witches 'of at the naill uith thaim.'  But Maitland is to make sure that Richie Grahme gets his ordinary allowance.
a letter from Bowes to Burghley saying that James VI has been occupied with the 'fast on Sunday' and the examination of witches.

Letter from Bowes to Burghley describing Ewphame Mackallean's trial and its impact on Bothwell's case.  He says that 'Kennedy the witch of Reydon, lately in England' will be more trouble to Bothwell.  Indicated 0 unnamed witches because both of the people mentioned here have records of their own.

column1: We know almost nothing about this accused witch.
column9: This witch (sex unspecified), lately in England, testified against Bothwell.

Sundry witches taken some that wished to harm the king.  This is from 'Notes on Scottish Affairs.  Because no specific number, other than 'sundry' was given in this source, I Indicated three unnamed witches in line with our usual estimating practice.

Bowes to Burghley, says that the king is in Stirling and that he has been lately troubled by witches, a McKolme Anderson confessed that he and others tried to drown the King as he passed over the water at Dundee at the General Assembly, and that the life of the Prince has also been sought by witches.  Counted 3 unnamed to account for the 'and others'.

column1: Described as confessing to trying to kill the King when travelling on the water to Dundee to attend a General Assembly meeting, and he named 'others'.
column9: Mentioned in a reportage about the king.

'The king has his mind only bent upon the examination and trial fo sorcerers, men and women.  Sut a great number are 'delated' that it is a wonder and those not only of the meanest sort but also of the best.'

the first letter is the response for request for protection from Sir George Home so he can resolve the matter of witchcraft trials.  It was granted.  The second was a restatement and an offer of protection to his son Alexander Home.

In this letter from the King to the advocate, he says that he has been informed that Alexander Hammilton confessed to witchcraft and delated others for practices against thelife and estate of Sir George Home .  But that Sir George Home was also accused of suborning witnesses.  The King told the advocate to sort it out and determine which party was lying.  This letter concerned procedures rather than Hammilton's specific case.

This letter from the King to the Lord of Lorne concerns the warrant from the Scottish Privy Council to arrest John Neill who was suspect of witchcraft.  Neill had fled into England.  The King's letter orders justice officials in the Northumberland to find him and send him back to Scotland for trial, to be handed over to Sir William Cockburne of Longtoune, the Sheriff of Berwick.
A commission from the General Assembly,  held in Edinburgh in 1646, requesting that charming be included in the remit of the 1563 witchcraft act.

column1: The record only has witness ratification of dittay items.  Doesn't say what the dittay said or what the witnesses ratefied.
column4: A woman found a lump of flesh in her bed in the shape of a hand and fell ill.  The same woman hired a woman from Dunblane to cure her with a drink.  A man cam to her for advice about the removal of a bewitchment.  She told the man to grip the suspected witch's coat tail and drink ale with her and ask for his health 3 times for God's sake.  She made bad predictions which came true.
column5: Prayed Malice on a man who made her pregnant and did nothing to help her.  Blair claimed a woman stopped being nice to her after Blair had healed her husband.

The Haddington porteous roll of delinquent dittays from 8/9/1679  (like the Edinburgh one of the same date) all have the standard tag line of accusations: witchcraft, sorcery and necromancy; and renunciation of baptism and giving themselves over to the Devil, body and soul.

column1: He was suspected then determined to be a witness not a suspect due to young age.  Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!
column3: confessed to being at three meetings but not to being a witch.  He claimed to have been present at the meeting to torment Christian Shaw, kill the minsiter Mr. John hardie and murder the boy Mathew Park.  He was accused but determined to be a witness not a suspect.
column9: Mentioned in the closing arguments of the last day of the only group trial to come out of the 1697 Renfrewshire cases.  Accused but not indicted for witchcraft.  Instead he and his brother were witnesses.  Deemed too young to have made a viable pact with the Devil.  Was not indicted with the large group on 13/4/1697 or tried with the seven who actually stood trial on 12/5/1697.

column1: Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!
column3: There were seven witches' meetings alleged in the Renfrew trials of 1697.  The meetings were said to have taken place in 1696 for the murder of a minister and several infants and children and the tormenting of Christian Shaw and other young people.  The participants supposedly danced, did image magic, met with the devil, and plotted bad things.  The meetings were described by a few people who confessed and several children who claimed to have been present.
column4: Accused of participating in 6 meetings where wax images with pins were used to enact murder and roasting the wax image was also used to kill and torment people.  One meeting to strangle a child took place at midnight in the kid's bedroom.  Apparently physical charmes made of bone, blood, and hair were found
column5: The group was accused of murdering children by strangulation. children were in fact murdered in this way by someone. Possession symptoms were thrassing,extraordinary strength,bite marks,welts, spitting pins and hair,vomit,and more.Caused possession fits.
column9: Part of the Renfrew cases of 1697 - one out of seven to make it to trial out of 28+ accused.

Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!
column3: see Agnes Naismith for details (c/egd/1773)
column4: allegedly part of a group that used image magic to kill people including children.
column9: Part of the Renfrewshire cases of 1697.

Christian Cauldwell (sometimes spelled Caddell) alias John Dickson was idicted as a common oppressor for dressing as a man and acting as a witchpricker.  She pretended to be a burgess from Forfar.  She was held in the tolbooth of Edinburgh 30 Aug. 1662 and interrogated by the justice deputes.  She mentioned two unnamed people she accused of witchcraft and many from six counties. (Estimate 2 witches from each county plus 2 for a total of 14 unnamed witches.)  As a man she contracted with officials in Moray to be their witch pricker for one year.  She was paid 6 shillings a day and Â£6 for every witch who was found guilty.  She travelled and worked with a woman named Issobell Dick.  She claimed she could tell witches by sight, by looking into their eyes and that she learned her skill by watching John Kincaid, a witch pricker active in the Lothians.  She was accused of pricking 'many of his majesties leiges' in the sheriffdoms of Elgin, Forres, Nairn, Inverness, Ross and Sutherland.

The Lawting Sheriff and Justice Court (much like the Court of the Bishopric later that same year, see c/la/3049) forbade the concealing of witchcraft and other crimes such as theft, murder, oppression, blood wrongs, etc.  This act was in a whole series of justice acts regarding all manner of things, hiring servants, weights and measures, etc.

He said he could identify the smell of witches because their carnal dealings with the Devil left an odour like a dead corpse.

The General Assembly was not happy that the civil magistrate was refusing to prosecute accused witches and setting some suspects free.  They resolved that Presbyteries should' proceed in all severities with their censures againis all such Magistrats as sall sett at liberties any person convict of witchcraft heirafter.'
A man was paid to do his office upon Bessie Bell and utheris for Â£4 11s. 4d. (same man from earlier Ayr trials).
Mr. Robert Ramsay declared from the pulpit, by the authority of the Presbytery, that people who were caught charming or resorting to charming would be prosecuted to the death for witchcraft.
The Church of Scotland petitioned Parliament to renew the acts about charmers, sorcerers and consulters - and that 'a solid way takin how the same acts may be put to execution.'

The minister of Straiton, Mr. Johne M'Quorne asked the Presbytery's advice as to whether or not he could take a woman in Galloway named Jeane M'Murran around his parish to identify witches.  He had sundry suspected witches as 'Jean took upon her the discoverie of witches throw the cuntrey.'  The answer was no, because the late General Assembly had 'condemed and discharged the foirsaid practice in all tyme coming'.
'Act and warrant for tryall of the torture of witches.'

The Baillie of Cuninghame told the presybery of Irvine that an assize would be held on 12 people who had confessed to witchcraft and that the execution would take place on the following Friday.  He requested the Presbytery to send ministers to wait upon them before their death, which the Presbytery did.  They sent 13 ministers.
Several parishes in the Presbytery of Irvine had confessing witches, so they recommended that the Presbytery write to the Privy Council for a commission of assize.

The Bailie of Cunninhame reported to the Presbytery that sundry people had been arrested within the bounds of the Presbytery without a warrant.  They should refrain from arresting people, and report to the Bailie if they have suspects.

'the Counsall remitts to the Magistratis as they think most fitting to give ordor als weill for imprisonning as for the payment of the chargis of these personnis apprehendit and delaitfor withcraft'  I take this to mean the people we already know about for Ayrshire at this time so I have not added any to the count of suspects.

Four witches were to be executed the next Saturday at Irvine, for witchcraft.  They appointed three additional ministers to attend to the execution.  This could be the execution of the four people for whom the Presbytery of Irvine requested a commission on 1 May 1650 (c/la/3205), (c/la/3133), (c/egd/1836), (c/la/3206).

The moderator of the Ayr presbytery 'made report that he had written to the states for a general commission against witches, as also to the baillies of carrik to use the like diligence against witches within there bounds.'

Ayr parish session ordered elders and deacons to make themselves available for 24 hours 'per vices both in the day and in the night, shall oversie the said prisoners to exhort them to confessione and to pray with them to God'.  An example of orders for wathcing and warding.

Ayr Kirk session mentioned that the first witches were burnt in Irvine.  I indicated 0 suspects because we have a many known suspects from Irvine, so these witches will get into the final count as individual witches.  This is to avoid double-counting suspects.

column1: At least 9 witchcraft suspects were tortured, four of them died.
column9: A letter from Mr. William Clarke to the Speaker of Parliament in Westminster described how at least seven witchcraft suspects were made to confess (about the time the armies came into Scotland).  They were first brought before the Kirk session and made to confess and then turned over to the civil magistrate.  The court claimed they were forced to confess through 'exceeding torture'.  They tied their 'thumbs behind them' and hanged them by them, they were whipped by two Highlanders, and had lighted candles put to the soles of their feet, between their toes and in their mouths.  Six were accused and four died from the torture.  Another suspect was kept 20 days on bread and water after being stripped naked and laid on a cold stone with only a hair-cloth.  Others had hair-shirts dipped in vinegar to 'fetch off their skin'.
The Synod, met at Paisley 'anent the business of witchcraft'.  They ordered 5 May 1697 as a day of humiliation and fasting.

The Clerk of the Synod wanted each presbytery to send 'some of their number' to Edinburgh to Parliament to have a say in their deliberations against 'poperie, prophanity, schism, and to crave a new and plainer Law against Adultery, Witchcraft, etc.'

The presbytery reported that several people were arrested from Dalry due to delation and 'mala fama'.   'They were apprehended by the Judge Ordinary' and were still impenitent [refusing to confess] therefore it is appointed that Mr. Patrick Colville and Mr. W. S. Russel, shall go to Dalry.'  They got one person to confess.  Because Mr. Robert Bell was unwell, infirm and short of hearing the Presbytery sent Mr. Robert Urie and Mr. James Rowat to exhort the remaining impenitent witches to confess.
Several people in Largs confessed to witchcraft and were recommended to the Committee of Estates for a commission.
Mr. Wm Guthrey and two ministers of Stewarton were appointed to deal with some people who were apprehended for witchcraft in the parish of Dreghorn.  They were supposed to bring them to a confession.

The Privy Council granted a commission of investigation to look into the witchcraft accusations made by Cristian Shaw.  The commission allows for investigation, witness depositions, and giving caution to stand trial.  But they needed permission to arrest suspects.  They were to report back to the Privy Council by 10 March.  That was done on 19/1/1697.  Then the Privy Council issued a commission to try 24 named people in Renfrewshire (their records are updated with this info.), the Privy Counicl agreed to appoint 'such a somme as they shall think fitt' for imprisoning and trying the Refrewshire witches.  That was from 9 March 1697.  This commission gives concrete instructions as to how the commissioners were required to set up court and run the trial.  The the Privy Council agreed to let the commissioners hold courts at Paisley, Glasgow or anywhere else in Renfrewshire this was on 5 April 1697.  By 4 October 1698 the sheriff depute wrote a letter to the Privy Council requesting further funds for the maintanence of people in prison or a commission to try them.  The Privy Council agreed to pass the matter over to the Lord advocate and to reimburse who ever maintained the suspects.  On 12 January 1699 the Privy Council authorised the Sheriff depute to maintain each prison with not more than one groat each per day to be reimbursed by the treasury.

column1: accused of charms, malefices and correspondence with the Devil.

The Privy Council entry also specifies 'unlawfull cures by unlawfull meanes'.

This is an unusual case.  She confessed to turning to the Devil to help her kill her first husband, which she did with a drink.  She also procured an abortion for her daughter who died from it.  She had been having an extramarital affair with her second husband while still married to the first.  She tried to kill herself at least three times, by hanging with her curch, cutting her throat while in prison, banging her head on the stocks.
column2: The devil nipped her check, which people could see on her face.
column4: She murdered her husband with a drink made of foxtree leaves and tried to give her daughter an abortion (a drink of wine and salt) that backfired when her daughter died.  Her grief and guilt seem to lay behind her confession.  She confessed that the Devil told her how to make both drinks.
column5: she murdered her husband and tried to give her daughter an abortion that backfired in her death.
column9: She tried to kill herself three times.  The appendix of 'Witchcraft Cases from the Register of Commissions of the Privy Council of Scotland, 1630-42', edited by L. Yeoman has the dates for her commission and trial for 1634.  There is a discrepancy with the dates.  The commission dated 30/12/1634 was clearly was issued before her trial, the date of which is listed as 6/1/1634.  Therefore I have set the trial date at 6/1/1635.

Had his servants record Alexander Hammiltoun's depositions against Lady Manderston because he was implicated by them.  He was arrested for lying about taking Hammiltoun's depositions, and was put to the horn, subsequently unable to pay for a further compearance before privy council.  Granted protection from the PC on 13/7/1630.  A complaint was made about his falsification of depositions against John Smith and Katharine Wilson of Duns.  The complaint was found proven and he was arrested in 5/7/1631. Involved in cases between1629 and 1631. Fawside may be Fawside (Falside) near Tranent as there does seem to be a Fawside in Berwick.

Don't know where he was minister. Involved in case in 1593. I think this may have been David Lindsay of Putturmie. He was minister at South Leith (Restalrig) from 1560 until 17th century but was actively involved in politics. He attended Assembly 50 times, was closely associated with James VI (he conducted marriage ceremony and baptism of royal children). Was appointed bishop of Ross and was member of Privy Council from 1600 and accompanied James to London. He kept his parish appointment but there seems to have been a reader there until his son took over in 1613. He seems to have been around a very long time.

column1: The commission was read out at Renfrew on 18/3/1697. This case was under a PC commission (see PC1/51 p. 136-9) along with most of the people tried at the same time. There were other Renfrewshire witchcraft suspects tried at different places and times. I am keeping this as a mixed/central local because the Privy Council maintained very strict control over the proceedings, even though they granted a commission.  For details of the proceedings of Privy Council in this matter see the no named witches case c/la/3235.

Fergusson and his beadle, Alexander Simpson, heard fearful voices.  She confessed to everything but the witchcraft.

There is also a dittay with a list of witnesses and another one from 6/4/1658  with details (21 male and 13 female witnesses).

column1: In 1591 on the 29 day of an illegible month he confessed.  He was kept in the house of David Seaton in Tranent.  Was questioned about Euphame Makcalyean, he said he never knew her until he saw her in the tolbooth in Edinburgh.  He implied that he was tortured to implicate Makcalyean, retracted it and said he will answer to God for what he said.  He was questioned about Bothwell on 19/9/1591.
Presbytery attested his confession.

column1: Order to be apprehended. Presbytery investigated accusations.

Testimony taken before the ministers at Dunfermline on 31 May 1624.  Testimony taken against him on 25 Oct. 1628 at Stirling (JC26/9 item 15) and 28 Oct. 1628 at Culross (JC26/9). Witness statements taken on 8 April 1629 under a commission from Privy Council (JC26/9 item 19).  Witness statements were taken all over Perthshire through 1628 and 1629 (see references)  Privy Council orded 8 shillings to be given for the maintenance of Drummond in the tolbooth of Edinburgh - 'for his interteanement and jaylour fee'; complaint about an ailment in prison 1/1629.  The presbytery of Muthill requested that the Privy Council move him to Edinburgh.  They interrogated him and took evidence on 6 April 1629 (JC26/9 item 6).  In his depositions/confessions he said he did do all the healing but that it was not witchcraft.  He was denounced as a rebel at Perth, in May 1624 and in October 1628.
column3: PC warrant for execution.  Dated 9/7/1629 the entry says 'Wednisday nixt'  I assume that is two days later (the entry before is described as happening on Tuesday).  After his execution a campaign was launched to posthumously clear his name.  Letters were written 6 Oct 1646 and 13 Dec 1646 to get the King to clear him.
